channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: U.S. Watched George Floyd Protests in 15 Cities Using Aerial Surveillance
item.description: From Minneapolis to Buffalo, Homeland Security officials dispatched drones, helicopters and airplanes to monitor Black Lives Matter protests.

item.title: Air Force Investigates Military Planes That Monitored Protesters
item.description: The Air Force inspector general is examining whether secretive National Guard surveillance aircraft improperly monitored demonstrators in Washington and Minneapolis.

item.title: Arctic Records Its Hottest Temperature Ever
item.description: Reaching 100 degrees in or near the Arctic is almost unheard of.

item.title: 'America Is Not the Greatest Country in the World Anymore' - The Newsroom
item.description: From the series 'the newsroom', the beginning scene. America is not the greatest country in the world anymore.

item.title: Ten Percent of U.S. High School Students Graduating Without Basic Object Permanence Skills
item.description: A new study finds that many American students do not realize that objects continue to exist even when they cannot be seen or heard.

item.title: China Believed to Be Behind Major Cyber Attack on Australian Governments and Businesses
item.description: Federal Government agencies believe China is the nation behind ongoing cyber attacks on Australian institutions, including hospitals, in recent months.

item.title: Combining Therapy With the Psychedelic Drug Psilocybin Results in Large Reductions in Anxiety and Depression
item.description: Psilocybin is a hallucinogenic compound found in so-called 'magic mushrooms'. A recent meta-analysis published in Psychiatry Research provides tentative ...

item.title: U.S. Ranked Worst for Workers' Rights Among Major Economies
item.description: The U.S. has the worst record among major developed countries when it comes to workers' rights, according to a survey of labor unions.

item.title: Millions of Abandoned Oil Wells Are Leaking Methane, a Climate Menace
item.description: (This June 16 story corrects comparison in paragraph eight of climate damage from methane leaks to that from U.S. oil consumption. The leaks cause climate damage roughly equivalent to typical U.S. oil consumption in one day, not two days.)

item.title: PG&E Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter: 'Our Equipment Started the fire.'
item.description: PG&E's 'gross negligence' led to massive 2018 Camp Fire, district attorney said.

item.title: Massive Spying on Users of Google's Chrome Shows New Security Weakness
item.description: A newly discovered spyware effort attacked users through 32 million downloads of extensions to Google's market-leading Chrome web browser, researchers at Awake Security told Reuters, highlighting the tech industry's failure to protect browsers as they are used more for email, payroll and other sensi…

item.title: How to Spot Police Surveillance Tools
item.description: Officers are likely tracking your every move at protests. But if you know what to look for, it's easy to protect yourself.

item.title: A $1.1m Hospital Bill After Surviving the Coronavirus? That's America for You
item.description: It shouldn't take a once-in-a-century pandemic to make policymakers understand the tragic absurdity of healthcare in the United States of America

item.title: The Auto Industry Is Wrecked—Let's Rebuild It With Electric
item.description: It's the perfect time for a transportation revolution: the Green-Car New Deal.

item.title: Universities Step Up the Fight for Open-Access Research
item.description: Today's deal between the University of California and publisher Springer Nature is a big milestone on the path to dismantling paywalls around academic journals.

item.title: The Russian Disinfo Operation You Never Heard About
item.description: The campaign known as Secondary Infektion appears to be a distinct effort from the meddling of the IRA and GRU—and it went undetected for years.

item.title: You Can Now Buy Spot the Robot Dog—if You've Got $74,500
item.description: Boston Dynamics is finally making its mechanical canine available for businesses and developers. But know that this puppy ain't for everyone.

item.title: Researchers Uncover Six-Year Russian Misinformation Campaign Across Facebook and Reddit
item.description: More than 2500 posts across 300 platforms

item.title: Multiple 'CIA Failures' Led to Theft of Agency's Top-Secret Hacking Tools
item.description: Vault 7, the worst data theft in CIA history, could have been avoided, report finds.

item.title: Political Groups Use 'Deeply Spooky' Protester Location Data, Report Finds
item.description: Activists want demonstrators to stay active—but privacy implications abound.

item.title: How Fighting Poverty Accidentally Stopped Deforestation
item.description: Evidence from Indonesia shows that development goals don’t have to come at a cost to the climate.

item.title: Zoom Shut Down US-Based Activists at China's Request
item.description: Hackers for hire, a particularly ignominious phishing campaign, and more of the week's top security news.

item.title: Three People With Inherited Diseases Successfully Treated With CRISPR
item.description: Two people with beta thalassaemia and one with sickle cell disease no longer need blood transfusions after their blood stem cells were gene edited and put back in their bodies

item.title: CEO Worked Way Up From Son of CEO
item.description: No description provided.

item.title: The Pandemic Is Propelling a New Wave of Automation
item.description: Software programs adopted during the Covid-19 crisis make it easier to complete forms and track requests. It saves work, but could cost jobs.

item.title: Powerful Petrochemical Lobbying Group Advanced Anti-Protest Legislation Amid Pandemic
item.description: West Virginia is one of several states that have taken advantage of the pandemic to ease the construction of controversial oil and gas projects.

item.title: Thousands of Tons of Microplastics Are Falling From the Sky
item.description: New research helps unravel how vast amounts of plastic particles travel—both regionally and globally—on the wind

item.title: Plastic Dust Is Blowing Into U.S. National Parks—More Than 1000 Tons Each Year
item.description: New study begins to trace a global 'plastic cycle'

item.title: Police Attacks on Protesters With 'Less Than Lethal' Weapons Result in Life-Threatening Injuries
item.description: People demonstrating on the streets, or following along online, don't need studies to know that less-lethal weaponry isn't safe — particularly in crowds.

item.title: U.S. States Accuse 26 Drugmakers of Generic Drug Price Fixing in Sweeping Lawsuit
item.description: Twenty-six drug manufacturers were sued on Wednesday by the attorneys general of most U.S. states and several territories, which accused them of conspiring to reduce competition and drive up generic drug prices.

item.title: 2 Million Cases and Counting: US COVID-19 Outbreak Charges on Amid Reopening
item.description: Despite testing boosts, experts say increases are real; fear of second wave looms.

item.title: New Facebook Tool Allows Employers to Suppress 'Unionize' in Workplace Chat
item.description: Facebook Workplace is used by employers as large as Walmart. The new tool would allow 'content control' to prevent certain topics from trending internally.

item.title: Siberian Officials Say Huge Diesel Spill Has Reached a Sensitive Arctic Lake
item.description: A major diesel spill from a power plant in Siberia has reached a fragile freshwater lake that leads to the Arctic Ocean, according to regional officials. That could create an ecological catastrophe.

item.title: MIT, Guided by Open Access Principles, Ends Elsevier Negotiations
item.description: Institute ends negotiations for a new journals contract in the absence of a proposal aligning with the MIT Framework for Publisher Contracts.

item.title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Isn't Ending — It's Surging
item.description: Good news from some nations and diverted attention in others doesn't stop the fact the overall picture is very grim.

item.title: Protesters Across US Attacked by Cars Driven Into Crowds and Men With Guns
item.description: Protesters confronted by armed men – including members of the so-called 'boogaloo movement' – in different parts of America

item.title: Britain Goes Coal Free as Fossil Fuels Edged Out
item.description: On Wednesday, Britain will mark two months without burning any coal to generate power.

item.title: Louisville Police Release the Breonna Taylor Incident Report. It's Nearly Blank
item.description: Nearly three months after police fatally shot Breonna Taylor, the department released the incident report. It is almost entirely blank.

item.title: Researchers Detail Huge Hack-for-Hire Campaigns Against Environmentalists
item.description: 'The extensive targeting of American nonprofits exercising their first amendment rights is exceptionally troubling.'

item.title: The Best Raspberry Pi Alternatives
item.description: If you're working on a project that a Pi can't tackle, here are five single-board computers that power any DIY demand.

item.title: Coronavirus Hospitalizations Rise Sharply in Several States Following Memorial Day
item.description: Since Memorial Day, covid-19 hospitalizations in at least nine states have been on the rise.

item.title: We Mapped Where Customs and Border Protection Drones Are Flying in the U.S. and Beyond
item.description: In 2011, Rodney Brossart, a cattle rancher from Lakota, North Dakota was accused of stealing six cows. The cows, he said, simply wandered on to his 3,000-acre farm, and by his estimation, they, therefore, belonged to him. When the cops came, he and his family were prepared. Armed with high power rif…

item.title: Police Officers Slashed Car Tires During Minneapolis Protests, Police Agencies Say
item.description: Dozens of cars in a Kmart parking lot had all their tires slashed after public anger over George Floyd's death sparked large protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: Hospitals Got Bailouts and Furloughed Thousands While Paying C.E.O.s Millions
item.description: Dozens of top recipients of government aid have laid off, furloughed or cut the pay of tens of thousands of employees.

item.title: To Save the Climate, Look to the Oceans
item.description: They can be a source of clean, renewable energy, sustainable food, and more

item.title: You Have a First Amendment Right to Record the Police
item.description: Like the rest of the world, we are horrified by the videos of George Floyd's murder. Once again, police brutality was documented by brave bystanders exercising their First Amendment rights. Their videos forcefully tell a painful truth that has further fueled a movement to demand an end to racism...

item.title: Yes, American Police Act Like Occupying Armies. They Literally Studied Their Tactics
item.description: The founders of modern policing quelled foreign uprisings. 'Demilitarizing' police will be harder than taking away their tanks

item.title: We Can No Longer Ignore the Potential of Psychedelic Drugs to Treat Depression
item.description: At Imperial College we've been comparing psilocybin to conventional antidepressants – and the results are likely to be game-changing, says Robin Carhart-Harris

item.title: A New CDC Survey Finds That Some Americans Are Misusing Disinfectants
item.description: A new survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has found that some Americans are misusing cleaning and disinfectant products to prevent coronavirus. Some practices include misting their bodies with disinfectant and gargling bleach.

item.title: It's Official: U.S. Economy Is in a Recession
item.description: The committee tasked with marking U.S. business cycles says the economy peaked in February and has since been in a recession triggered by the pandemic. But it says the recession could be short-lived.

item.title: Protests About Police Brutality Are Met With Wave of Police Brutality Across US
item.description: Use of teargas, batons, pepper spray, fists, feet and vehicles against protesters sparks lawsuits and international condemnation

item.title: Police Tactics Could Turn Protests Into Covid-19 Hot Spots
item.description: Sure, large crowds already carry a risk of transmission. It's just worse when you teargas people, make them cough on each other, and bus them to jail.

item.title: The Unluckiest Generation in U.S. History
item.description: Millennials have faced the worst economic odds, and many will never recover.

item.title: Police Misconduct Records Are Secret. Protests May Finally Change That.
item.description: A decades-old New York State law that has kept police behavior from public scrutiny may finally be overturned.

item.title: Trump Signs Order Removing Environmental Review of Major Projects
item.description: President Trump signed an executive order Thursday evening that would waive requirements under a suite of environmental laws, a move the administration says will boost the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Amid Pandemic and Protests, Trump Fast-Tracks Dangerous Fossil Fuel Infrastructure
item.description: Amid nationwide protests against racist police brutality and a pandemic that's disproportionately affecting Black people, on Thursday night, Trump signed an executive order directing federal agencies to fast track the construction of projects that will put communities of color at risk.

item.title: Americans Are Drinking Bleach and Dunking Food in It to Prevent COVID-19
item.description: Thirty-nine percent of surveyed people admitted to at least one risky practice.

item.title: Pentagon War Game Includes Scenario for Military Response to Domestic Gen Z Rebellion
item.description: The 2018 war game envisioned a 'Zbellion' by a tech-savvy generation that no longer believed in the American dream.

item.title: Buffalo Police Said Protester With Head Wound 'Tripped and Fell.' Video Shows They Lied.
item.description: Police officers in Buffalo, New York were caught on camera shoving a 75-year-old protester to the ground, injuring him at a protest against police brutality.

item.title: COVID Vaccine Execs Hyped Vague Data to Cash in $90M in Stock, Watchdog Says
item.description: Executives allegedly 'exploited widespread fears' of pandemic to make millions.

item.title: A Massive Oil Spill in the Arctic Has Turned a River Red
item.description: Russia declared a state of emergency after a power plant spilled 20,000 metric tons of oil and diesel fuel into a river in the Arctic Circle. The possible cause: melting permafrost due to climate change.

item.title: All This Chaos Might Be Giving You 'Crisis Fatigue'
item.description: Your body is well adapted to handle temporary stresses, but it's overwhelmed by the constant, unrelenting pressures of this horrible year.

item.title: Harvard Shrank Its Insect-Inspired Microrobot to the Size of a Penny
item.description: Harvard researchers have made the tiny Harvard Ambulatory Microrobot (HAMR) even tinier. The next-gen HAMR-JR is one of the smallest and fastest microrobots to date.

item.title: Earth's Carbon Dioxide Levels Hit Record High, Despite Coronavirus-Related Emissions Drop
item.description: Carbon dioxide levels are now the highest they've been in human history, and likely the highest in 3 million years.

item.title: Tear Gas Is Way More Dangerous Than Police Let on — Especially During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: In the middle of a respiratory pandemic, law enforcement agencies have used tear gas in especially dangerous ways. The chemical agent also seeps into homes, contaminates food, furniture, skin and surfaces, and can cause long-term lung damage.

item.title: How US Police Used Military Tactics to Turn Peaceful Protests Violent
item.description: What would have happened had police taken a calmer approach at the beginning of the protests? Well, look at what happened in Baltimore

item.title: We Crunched the Numbers: Police — Not Protesters — Are Overwhelmingly Responsible for Attacking Journalists
item.description: Protests over the killing of George Floyd have seen attacks on the press spike. Our data shows police are responsible for more than 80 percent of them.

item.title: New PFAS Chemical Contamination Discovered in New Jersey
item.description: Eight variations of a newly identified group of PFAS compounds were found near a Solvay plant in West Deptford, New Jersey.

item.title: Buffalo Police Officers Suspended After Shoving 75-Year-Old Protester
item.description: A video showed the protester motionless on the ground and bleeding. Fifty-seven officers resigned from the department's Emergency Response Team in solidarity with the two who were suspended.

item.title: NYPD Officers at George Floyd Protests Are Covering Their Badge Numbers in Violation of Own Policy
item.description: The National Lawyers Guild threatened to sue the city if NYPD officers did not end the widespread practice of covering their badge numbers.

item.title: Minneapolis Cops Sued for Shooting, Beating, and Gassing Over a Dozen Journalists
item.description: The ACLU has filed a class-action lawsuit against Minnesota authorities on behalf of journalists whom state and local police were filmed beating, shooting, gassing, and arresting during protests against the police killing of George Floyd.

item.title: 'Let's Start a Riot': Denver Cop Fired for Inflammatory Instagram Post
item.description: Post was 'inconsistent with the values of the Department,' investigation found.

item.title: SpaceX Launches 60 More Starlink Satellites and Achieves a Reusability Record for a Falcon 9 Booster
item.description: SpaceX launched its second Falcon 9 rocket in the span of just four days on Wednesday at 9:25 PM EDT (6:25 PM PDT). This one was carrying 60 more satellites for its Starlink constellation, which will bring the total currently in operation on orbit to 480. The launch took off from Florida, where Spa…

item.title: More Than 70 Children Killed in Just 10 Airstrikes in Afghanistan, Report Finds
item.description: The Bureau of Investigative Journalism analyzed 10 strikes by the U.S. military and the U.S.-backed Afghan air force and found 115 civilians were killed.

item.title: US Cop Hits Australian Cameraman Live on National Television
item.description: 'You heard us yelling that we were media, but they don't care,' reporter said.

item.title: Millions of Americans Skip Payments as Tidal Wave of Defaults and Evictions Looms
item.description: Hardship programs appear to be helping many people pause payments and survive the economic shutdown so far. But not everybody is getting the help, and advocates see big potential trouble ahead.

item.title: CIA Veterans Who Monitored Crackdowns Abroad See Troubling Parallels in Trump's Handling of Protests
item.description: For former U.S. intelligence officials, scenes of armed clashes and strongman poses are familiar signs of a fraying country.

item.title: What the Future of the Space Station Looks Like After SpaceX's Historic Launch
item.description: The paradigm of human spaceflight for the last nine years is about to change

item.title: Big Pharma Attacks Efforts to Guard Against Coronavirus Price Gouging
item.description: A coalition of conservative groups, many funded by the pharmaceutical industry, have attacked proposals aiming to ensure Covid-19 treatments are affordable.

item.title: Influencers Reemerge, Worse Than Ever
item.description: A Santa Monica area influencer was caught borrowing a worker's drill to stage a photo-op outside a boarded-up shop damaged by the previous night's looting. Toting a photographer/boyfriend, the woman hands the drill back to a worker and climbs into a Mercedes-Benz and scurries away, pronouncing 'Good…

item.title: 'Nonlethal' Anti-Protest Weapons Can Cause Serious Harm
item.description: Rubber bullets and tear gas are billed as relatively safe. They're anything but.

item.title: A Short History of U.S. Law Enforcement Infiltrating Protests
item.description: For decades, local police and FBI have sent undercover officials to participate in — and escalate — protests.

item.title: The NYPD Knows It Can Get Away With Attacking Protesters
item.description: The NYPD has long been shielded from accountability. This week's violent response to protesters exposed the extent of the department's culture of impunity.

item.title: Earth Is Accelerating Towards Sixth Mass Extinction That Could See 'End of Civilisation'
item.description: Stop The Wildlife Trade: 'Extinction breeds extinction', says grim new study revealing more than 500 species are on course to go extinct in next two decades - around the same figure for the whole of the twentieth century

item.title: Trump Demands Journalists Correct Stories on the Use of Tear Gas. According to the CDC, It Was Tear Gas.
item.description: The truth about what was deployed on Lafayette Square protesters to make way for the president's photo op boils down to an exercise in semantics.

item.title: Trump Is Talking About Using Tanks to Quell the George Floyd Protests, but the Pentagon Is Getting Cold Feet
item.description: Pentagon officials said Defense Secretary Mark Esper's urgings that states 'dominate the battlespace' was more a show of loyalty.

item.title: Google Faces $5 Billion Lawsuit in U.S. for Tracking 'Private' Internet Use
item.description: Google was sued on Tuesday in a proposed class action accusing the internet search company of illegally invading the privacy of millions of users by pervasively tracking their internet use through browsers set in 'private' mode.

item.title: The Pentagon's Hand-Me-Downs Helped Militarize Police. Here's How
item.description: Over several decades, the 1033 program has shipped over $7.4 billion of Defense Department property to more than 8,000 law enforcement agencies.

item.title: Tear Gas Is Dangerous and Should Be Illegal
item.description: Tear gas is a chemical weapon that is banned for use in warfare, yet U.S. police have repeatedly deployed it against people protesting police brutality and anti-black violence this week. Though it's considered a non-lethal weapon, tear gas is actually far more dangerous than advertised—especially i…

item.title: California Supreme Court Rules Cops Can't Bury Public Record Requests With Redaction Fees
item.description: A recent California Supreme Court decision has ruled that government agencies in the state can't pass on the costs of privacy redactions in the course of fulfilling records requests. According to the ruling, the cost of redacting records that citizens file under the California Public Records Act (CP…

item.title: Your Phone Is a Goldmine of Hidden Data for Cops. Here's How to Fight Back
item.description: For the thousands of people protesting and reporting on George Floyd's death at the hands of the Minneapolis Police Department—or even for bystanders caught up in the demonstrations—arrests, injuries, and even death are becoming commonplace in this moment. And just like protests we've experienced wi…

item.title: Mass Extinctions Are Accelerating, Scientists Report
item.description: Five hundred species are likely to become extinct over the next two decades, according to a new study.

item.title: British Photographer Arrested at George Floyd Protests in 'Affront to Press Freedom'
item.description: 'One big cop came at me and pushed me to the ground with his truncheon to my chest,' says Adam Gray – hit with unlawful assembly charge after taking photos of protesters

item.title: Major Breakthrough Allows Robot Hand to 'See and Feel' Objects as Fragile as a Crisp
item.description: 'We wish to enable seeing the world by feeling the world,' researchers say

item.title: An Onslaught of Crises Has Created a Modern Paradox
item.description: Never before have humans lived more comfortably. And yet today we're overwhelmed by crises, be it inequality or economic collapse or Covid, all exacerbating one another.

item.title: Trump Just Threatened to Use the U.S. Military Against Americans
item.description: Trump's plan involves invoking a two-century-old law known as the Insurrection Act, which allows the president to deploy troops inside the country.

item.title: After Dragon's Historic Docking, America Has More New Spaceships on the Way
item.description: 'It flew really well, very crisp. We couldn't be happier.'

item.title: U.S. Police Have Attacked Journalists More Than 130 Times Since May 28
item.description: 'Although in some incidents it is possible the journalists were hit or affected accidentally, in the majority of the cases we have recorded the journalists are clearly identifiable as press, and it is clear that they are being deliberately targeted.'

item.title: More Than 500 Vertebrate Species Are on the Brink of 'Biological Annihilation'
item.description: A new study finds further evidence that humans are driving the world's sixth mass extinction. Published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences Monday, this research focuses on terrestrial vertebrates—amphibians, birds, mammals, and reptiles—and found that more than 500 species are 'o…

item.title: U.S. Army's New Drone Swarm May Be a Weapon of Mass Destruction
item.description: The Cluster Swarm project is developing a warhead to dispense a swarm of drones that fan out to automatically locate and destroy vehicles with explosively formed penetrators. It seems likely to be able to inflict an immense amount of harm but inable to distinguish civilians from military targets.

item.title: Animal Rights Activists Uncover the Locations of Thousands of Factory Farms
item.description: The animal agriculture industry has spent decades fighting to avoid the disclosure of information about facilities where animals are raised for food.

item.title: George Floyd Protests: Reporters Targeted by Police and Crowds
item.description: Journalists report and record being shot at, teargassed, arrested and intimidated

item.title: How to Protest Safely in the Age of Surveillance
item.description: Law enforcement has more tools than ever to track your movements and access your communications. Here's how to protect your privacy if you plan to protest.

item.title: SpaceX Launched Two Astronauts—Changing Spaceflight Forever
item.description: The test mission will clear the way for regular crewed launches from the United States for the first time in nearly a decade.

item.title: The George Floyd Killing Exposes the Failures of Police Reform
item.description: As protests engulf Minneapolis after yet another police killing, advocates across the country say the time for police reform is over.

item.title: Border Patrol Flies Anti-Terrorism Drone Over Minneapolis Protestors
item.description: A Predator B drone from near-by Airforce bases makes six passes over protestors.

item.title: 135-Year-Long Streak Is Over: US Renewable Sources Topped Coal in 2019
item.description: Including wood and biofuels across all sectors, coal fell short last year.

item.title: Facial Recognition and License Plate Readers: Here Are the Surveillance Tools Used by the Minneapolis Police Department
item.description: As protesters demonstrate in Minneapolis in response to George Floyd's death, law enforcement agencies have access to a host of surveillance tools that could make it easier to target and find them.

item.title: Twitter Hides Trump Tweet for 'Glorifying Violence'
item.description: For the first time, Twitter has hidden a tweet on the president's profile behind a warning.

item.title: CNN Journalists Arrested Live on Air While Covering George Floyd Protests
item.description: CNN has reported that its correspondent Omar Jimenez, producer Bill Kirkos and photojournalist Leonel Mendez have been released from police custody after they were arrested in Minneapolis live on air.

item.title: A.C.L.U. Accuses Clearview AI of Privacy 'Nightmare Scenario'
item.description: The facial recognition start-up violated the privacy of Illinois residents by collecting their images without their consent, the civil liberties group says in a new lawsuit.

item.title: The CDC Released New Death Rate Estimates for the Coronavirus. Many Scientists Say They're Too Low.
item.description: Public health experts are accusing the CDC of bending under political pressure to say the coronavirus is less deadly.

item.title: NSA Warns of Ongoing Russian Hacking Campaign Against U.S. Systems
item.description: The U.S. National Security Agency on Thursday warned government partners and private companies about a Russian hacking operation that uses a special intrusion technique to target operating systems often used by industrial firms to manage computer infrastructure.

item.title: Mining Company Blows Up 46,000-Year-Old Aboriginal Site, Expresses No Regrets
item.description: A culturally important archaeological site in Western Australia was destroyed this past weekend during the expansion of an iron ore mine. Upsettingly, the mining company responsible for the incident did so with state permission, exposing Australia's weak and bigoted heritage conservation laws.

item.title: ACLU Sues Clearview AI Over Alleged Privacy Violations
item.description: The ACLU has sued Clearview AI for allegedly violating Illinois privacy law through its face recognition-based surveillance technology.

item.title: Leaked Draft Details Trump's Likely Attack on Technology Giants
item.description: Draft executive order claims that technology giants have 'dangerous power.'

item.title: Bad State Data Hides Coronavirus Threat as Trump Pushes Reopening
item.description: Test counts inflated, death tolls deflated, metrics shifted.

item.title: After Twitter Fact-Check, Trump Threatens to Regulate or Close Down Social Media Platforms
item.description: Once again, Donald Trump has doubled down. Following the addition of a fact-checking warning label added to his tweet about mail-in ballots, Trump took to the platform yet again to denounce it. In what may be his strongest words to date against a service that has largely given him free rein to this…

item.title: FBI Investigates Death of Black Man After Footage Shows Officer Kneeling on His Neck
item.description: Four officers fired in wake of death of George Floyd, who told Minneapolis police: 'I cannot breathe'

item.title: 100,000 Americans Dead—and Counting—as COVID-19 Ravages US
item.description: US leads the world in cases and deaths—and the pandemic is far from over.

item.title: Whistleblowers Say Facebook Has Not Warned Investors About Illegal Activity, in New SEC Complaint
item.description: The whistleblower's complaint claims the social media giant is aware of illegal activity on its platform, such as the sale of opioids, and has failed to properly police it.

item.title: Revealed: Conservative Group Fighting to Restrict Voting Tied to Powerful Dark Money Network
item.description: Honest Elections Project, part of network that pushed supreme court pick Brett Kavanaugh, is now focusing on voting restrictions

item.title: New Material Releases Hydrogen From Water at Near-Perfect Efficiency
item.description: Only works at UV wavelengths, but it might point the way toward general approach.

item.title: How the Fed Bailed Out the Investor Class Without Spending a Cent
item.description: Just announcing $4.5 trillion in future spending to support securities markets was enough to keep investors protected from the downsides of the pandemic.

item.title: YouTube Says That an Error Caused Comments Critical of China's Government to Auto-Delete
item.description: YouTube responded to reports that it is automatically deleting comments criticizing the Chinese government, explaining that the seeming censorship is actually an error in its automated moderation systems. As the Verge reported, comments on the platform using the Chinese phrases for 'communist…

item.title: House Leaders Strike Deal to Protect U.S. Web Browsing Data From Warrantless Surveillance
item.description: After three days of negotiations, House lawmakers have struck a deal on an amendment aimed at protecting innocent Americans from being spied on by their own government online.

item.title: FBI Investigating Ahmaud Arbery Shooting as Possible Hate Crime, Lawyer Says
item.description: Attorney for family of black jogger shot by white men says federal authorities are looking into prosecutors and police in case

item.title: Local News Stations Run Propaganda Segment Scripted and Produced by Amazon
item.description: At least 11 TV stations aired an identical segment written and produced by Amazon's PR team.

item.title: Twitter's First Fact-Check on President Trump Calls Out 'False Claims' [Updated]
item.description: Twitter: 'Get the facts.' Trump: 'Twitter is completely stifling FREE SPEECH.'

item.title: NASA and SpaceX Confirm SpaceX's First Ever Astronaut Launch Is a 'Go'
item.description: NASA and SpaceX are closer than ever to a moment both have been preparing for since the beginning of the Commercial Crew program in 2010. SpaceX's Falcon 9 and Crew Dragon spacecraft are now set to fly with NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken onboard, making a trip to the Internationa…

item.title: Hong Kong's Government Is Now Calling Pro-Democracy Protesters 'Terrorists'
item.description: Hong Kong's protesters are back, and the Beijing-backed government says their return only underscores the need for new treason and sedition laws.

item.title: A Third of Americans Now Show Signs of Clinical Anxiety or Depression, Census Bureau Finds Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Symptoms of anxiety and depression are widespread during the pandemic, according to the Census Bureau's new Household Pulse Survey.

item.title: US Beaches, Parks Full on Memorial Day Weekend Despite Pandemic
item.description: Health officials issue warnings after some revellers did not follow precautions while marking the beginning of summer.

item.title: A Massive Database of 8 Billion Thai Internet Records Leaks
item.description: The unprotected database contained DNS queries on millions of Thail internet users.

item.title: Inside the NSA's Secret Tool for Mapping Your Social Network
item.description: Edward Snowden revealed the agency's phone-record tracking program. But thanks to 'precomputed contact chaining,' that database was much more powerful than anyone knew.

item.title: Coronavirus in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Count
item.description: A detailed county map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with tables of the number of cases by county.

item.title: The Story of Cheaper Batteries, From Smartphones to Teslas
item.description: The economics of cheaper batteries—and why they're good news for the planet.

item.title: No Masks Allowed: Stores Turn Customers Away in US Culture War
item.description: Shops around the US make headlines for denying entry to those wearing masks as protesters argue against preventative measures in the name of freedom

item.title: Researchers Squeeze 44.2 Tbps Through Existing Fiber Optic Cables

item.description: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang left out the word 'peaceful' on Friday in referring to Beijing's desire to 'reunify' with Chinese-claimed Taiwan, an apparent policy shift that comes as ties with Taipei continue on a downward spiral.
